raw_text: The first four lines show the token-level accuracy for standard POS tagging tools trained and evaluated on the BulTreeBank:2 TreeTagger (Schmid, 1994), which uses decision trees, TnT (Brants, 2000), which uses a hidden Markov model, SVMtool (Gime ?nez and Ma`rquez, 2004), which is based on support vector machines, and ACOPOST (Schro ?der, 2002), implementing the memory-based model of Daelemans et al (1996) .The following lines report the token-level accuracy reported in previous work, as compared to our own experiments using guided learning
clean_text: The first four lines show the token-level accuracy for standard POS tagging tools trained and evaluated on the BulTreeBank:2 TreeTagger (Schmid, 1994), which uses decision trees, TnT (Brants, 2000), which uses a hidden Markov model, SVMtool (Gimenez and Ma`rquez, 2004), which is based on support vector machines, and ACOPOST (Schroder, 2002), implementing the memory-based model of Daelemans et al (1996).

raw_text: In that table, TBL stands for Brill ' s transformation-based error-driven tagget (Brill, 1995), ME stands for a tagger based on the ma ?imum entropy modelling (Ratnaparkhi, 1996), SPATTER stands for a statistical parser based on decision trees (Magerman, 1996), IGTREE stands for the memory-based tagger by Daelemans et al (1996), and, finally, TComb stands for a tagger that works by combination of a statistical trigram-based tagger, 59 Tagger TBL ME SPATTER IGTREE TComb STT+ (CPD+ENS) Train Test 950 Kw 150 Kw
clean_text: In that table, TBL stands for Brill ' s transformation-based error-driven tagget (Brill, 1995), ME stands for a tagger based on the maximum entropy modelling (Ratnaparkhi, 1996), SPATTER stands for a statistical parser based on decision trees (Magerman, 1996), IGTREE stands for the memory-based tagger by Daelemans et al (1996), and, finally, TComb stands for a tagger that works by combination of a statistical trigram-based tagger, 59 Tagger TBL ME SPATTER IGTREE TComb STT+ (CPD+ENS) Train Test 950 Kw 150 Kw.

citing_paper_authors: Dekai, Wu | Grace, Ngai | Marine, Carpuat
raw_text: The English data was automatically labeled with part-of-speech and chunk tags from the memory-based tagger and chunker (Daelemans et al, 1996), and the German data was labelled with the decision-tree-based TreeTagger (Schmidt, 1994)
clean_text: The English data was automatically labeled with part-of-speech and chunk tags from the memory-based tagger and chunker (Daelemans et al, 1996), and the German data was labelled with the decision-tree-based TreeTagger (Schmidt, 1994).

citing_paper_authors: Antal, van den Bosch | Walter, Daelemans
raw_text: Direct feedback loops that copya predicted output label to the input representation of the next example have been used in symbolic machine-learning architectures such as the the maximum-entropy tagger described by Ratnaparkhi (1996) and the memory-based tagger (MBT) proposed by Daelemans et al (1996)
clean_text: Direct feedback loops that copy a predicted output label to the input representation of the next example have been used in symbolic machine-learning architectures such as the the maximum-entropy tagger described by Ratnaparkhi (1996) and the memory-based tagger (MBT) proposed by Daelemans et al (1996).

raw_text: We used the provided POS annotation in Dutch (Daelemans et al, 1996) and a minimally supervised tagger (Yarowsky and Cucerzan, 2002) for Spanish to restrict the space of words accepted by the discriminators (e.g .is_B_candidate rejects prepositions, conjunctions, pronouns, adverbs, and those determiners that are the first word in the sentence)
clean_text: We used the provided POS annotation in Dutch (Daelemans et al, 1996) and a minimally supervised tagger (Yarowsky and Cucerzan, 2002) for Spanish to restrict the space of words accepted by the discriminators (e.g .is_B_candidate rejects prepositions, conjunctions, pronouns, adverbs, and those determiners that are the first word in the sentence).

raw_text: Comparing our tree-induction algorithm and IGTREE, the algorithm used in MBT (Daelemans et al, 1996), their main difference is that IGTREE produces oblivious decision trees by supplying an a priori ordered list of best features instead of re-computing the best feature during each branching, which is our case
clean_text: Comparing our tree-induction algorithm and IGTREE, the algorithm used in MBT (Daelemans et al, 1996), their main difference is that IGTREE produces oblivious decision trees by supplying an a priori ordered list of best features instead of re-computing the best feature during each branching, which is our case.

citing_paper_authors: Sabine, Buchholz | Erwin, Marsi
raw_text: Its original PoS tag set is very coarse and the PoS and the word stem information is not veryreliable.25 We therefore decided to re tag the tree bank automatically using the Memory-Based Tagger (MBT) (Daelemans et al, 1996) which uses a very fine-grained tag set
clean_text: Its original PoS tag set is very coarse and the PoS and the word stem information is not very reliable. We therefore decided to retag the tree bank automatically using the Memory-Based Tagger (MBT) (Daelemans et al, 1996) which uses a very fine-grained tag set.
